textContent.title: Welcome to the CMPD Use of Force Training Program
textContent.content: This training program is designed to provide officers with comprehensive guidance on the proper application of force in accordance with department policy and legal standards.

items: Understand the legal framework governing use of force
Learn to assess threat levels and respond appropriately
Develop decision-making skills for high-pressure situations
Recognize the importance of de-escalation techniques

textContent.title: Use of Force Training
textContent.content: The following presentation has been developed to provide officers with guidance regarding the proper application of force in accordance with departmental directives and legal standards.

textContent.title: This training covers:
items: Legal framework for use of force
Departmental policies and procedures
Proper techniques and decision-making
Documentation and reporting requirements

textContent.title: Cape May Police Department Policy
textContent.content: It is the policy of the Cape May Police Department that officers hold the highest regard for the dignity and liberty of all persons and place minimal reliance upon the use of force and instead use de-escalation tactics to the extent possible under the circumstances.

items: Officers shall use only that degree of force that is reasonable, necessary, and proportional considering the totality of the circumstances
Officers must consider the subject's mental and physical condition
Officers must consider the nature of the offense
Officers must consider the level of resistance or threat known at the time

textContent.content: This department respects and values the sanctity of human life and the application of deadly force is a measure to be employed only in the most extreme circumstances.

Officers whose actions are consistent with the law and the provisions of this policy will be strongly supported by the law enforcement community in any subsequent review of their conduct regarding the use of force.

slide_04.title: Core Principle One: Sanctity of Human Life

textContent.title: The Sanctity of Human Life and Serving the Community
textContent.content: In serving the community, officers shall make every effort to preserve and protect human life and the safety of all persons. Officers shall also respect and uphold the dignity of all persons at all times in a non-discriminatory manner.

items: Every officer shall respect the sanctity of human life and the dignity of every person
Officers shall act to preserve every life, whenever possible
Officers shall avoid unnecessary injury to members of the public or themselves
A respectful and cooperative relationship with the community is essential for effective law enforcement
This relationship can be undermined when force is used unnecessarily or unequally

slide_05.title: Core Principle Two: Force as Last Resort

textContent.title: Force as a Last Resort and Duty to De-Escalate
textContent.content: Force shall only be used as a last resort when necessary to accomplish lawful objectives that cannot reasonably be achieved through verbal commands, critical decision making, tactical deployment or de-escalation techniques. Force shall never be used as a retaliatory or punitive measure.

items: Effectuating a lawful arrest or detention
Carrying out a lawful search
Overcoming resistance directed at the officer or others
Preventing physical harm to the officer or another person
Protecting the officer or third party from unlawful force
Preventing property damage or loss
To punish a person or to retaliate against them for past conduct
As a lesson to prevent a person from resisting or fleeing in the future
To resolve a situation more quickly, unless delay would risk safety or significantly interfere with legitimate law enforcement objectives

textContent.title: Critical Decision-Making Model
textContent.content: Critical decision-making and tactical deployment techniques include tactical communication and tactical positioning, such as strategic redeployment and time as a tactic.

items: Begin critical assessment and planning prior to arriving at the scene
Collect available information
Assess situations, threats, and risks
Identify options for conflict resolution
Determine the best course of action
Act, review and reassess the situation as it evolves

textContent.title: What is De-escalation?
textContent.content: De-escalation is the action of communicating verbally or nonverbally in an attempt to reduce, stabilize, or eliminate the immediacy of a threat. De-escalation may also be used to create the time needed to allow the situation to resolve itself or to position additional resources to resolve the situation with the least amount of force necessary.

items: Communication techniques to calm an agitated subject (e.g., regulating tone and pitch, speaking slowly in a calm voice)
Rational decision-making techniques, such as ensuring that only one officer addresses the person while others remain detached as safety permits
Active listening techniques, such as sharing the officer's name, asking the subject their name, and exhibiting a genuine willingness to listen
Slowing down the pace of the incident by taking deep breaths, slowing speech, and applying strategic thinking
Using calming gestures and facial expressions (e.g., arms extended with palms out and avoiding angry expressions)
Procedural-justice techniques, such as explaining the officer's actions and responding to questions
Provide clear instructions and warnings
Attempt to determine whether the person has a special need, mental condition, physical limitation, developmental disability, or language barrier
State the consequences of refusing to comply with a mandatory directive, including that force will be used unless the person complies
Give the suspect a reasonable opportunity to comply
Obtain information from available sources including family members, caregivers or others who know the individual
Decrease exposure to potential threats by moving to a safer position
Slow down the pace of the incident
Call for specialized resources (Crisis Intervention Team, behavioral health providers, negotiators, qualified bi-lingual officers)
Use time as a de-escalation strategy

textContent.title: Duty to Use Only Objectively Reasonable, Necessary, and Proportional Force
textContent.content: Officers shall use the least amount of force that is objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional to safely achieve the legitimate law enforcement objective under the circumstances.

items: Immediacy and severity of the threat to officers or the public
Conduct of the individual being confronted, as reasonably perceived by the officer at the time
Officer and subject characteristics (e.g., age, size, relative strength, skill level, injuries sustained, level of exhaustion or fatigue)
Effects of drugs or alcohol on the subject
Mental state or capacity of the individual
Proximity of weapons or dangerous improvised devices
The degree to which the subject has been effectively restrained and their ability to resist despite being restrained
The availability of other options and possible effectiveness
The seriousness of the suspected offense or reason for contact with the individual
The officer's training and experience
The potential for injury to officers, suspects, and the public

textContent.title: Understanding Resistance Levels
textContent.content: The level of resistance that an officer encounters is a key factor in determining the appropriate amount of force that may be used in response. The less resistance an officer faces, the less force the officer should use.

items: If the individual's resistance diminishes, the officer shall immediately reduce the level of force used.
If the individual stops resisting entirely, the officer must immediately cease using force.
Flight from an officer does not, on its own, qualify a person as an assailant.

textContent.title: Special Requirements for Displaying Firearms
textContent.content: Unholstering or pointing a firearm are tactics that should be used with great caution. The presence of an officer's firearm, under the right circumstances, can discourage resistance and ensure officer safety without the need to resort to force.

items: Unnecessarily or prematurely drawing a firearm could limit an officer's options in controlling a situation
It could create greater anxiety on the part of the public
It could result in an unwarranted or accidental discharge of the firearm

textContent.title: Understanding Positional Asphyxiation
textContent.content: Positional asphyxiation is insufficient intake of oxygen as a result of body position that interferes with the subject's ability to breathe. It can occur during the process of subduing and restraining a person by placing the person in a posture that prevents or impedes the mechanism of normal breathing.

items: Verbal complaints of being unable to breathe properly
Visual signs of struggling or increased effort to breathe
Gurgling/gasping sounds with foam or mucus from nose or mouth
Heightened aggression during restraint (fighting for air)
Sudden behavioral changes (violent to quiet, or suddenly more aggressive)
Blue discoloration of facial skin (cyanosis)
Swelling, redness or blood spots to the face or neck
Any loss or reduced level of consciousness
As soon as handcuffed and restrained, a person should be immediately rolled to the side and taken to an upright position that does not impede normal breathing
Avoid putting sustained pressure on the neck or back, as breathing can be restricted even in the recovery position
Continuously monitor the person's condition while being restrained
When possible, designate a 'Safety Officer' to monitor health and welfare during restraint
Do not transport the arrested person in the prone position
Monitor the subject prior to, during, and at the conclusion of transport

textContent.content: Critical Warning: If the person cannot escape from the position, death may occur very rapidly. Restraint in the prone position presents a significant risk of asphyxia, particularly when a person is handcuffed and left in a face-down position.

slide_13.title: Core Principle Four: Deadly Force as Last Resort

textContent.title: Duty to Use Deadly Force Only as an Absolute Last Resort
textContent.content: Deadly force shall only be used as an absolute last resort and in strict compliance with department policy. Other actions by law enforcement that create a substantial risk of death or serious bodily injury must be avoided or employed only under the strictest of conditions.

items: Applying a chokehold, carotid artery restraint, or similar technique that involves pressure on the neck
Sitting, kneeling, or standing on a person's chest, back, or neck for a prolonged period of time
Intentionally driving a vehicle at or in the direction of a person with the intent to strike the individual
Using a baton or other weapon to intentionally strike an individual in the head or neck area
When feasible, officers shall attempt to de-escalate situations, issue verbal warnings, or use non-lethal force with the goal of resolving encounters without using deadly force
Officers shall not use deadly force if a reasonably available alternative will avert or eliminate an imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury and achieve the law enforcement purpose safely
When feasible, prior to using deadly force the officer shall identify themselves as a law enforcement officer and give a clear verbal warning to the suspect that the officer will use deadly force
Officers shall not use deadly force when the use of deadly force creates a substantial risk of injury to innocent persons

textContent.title: Specific Prohibited Circumstances
textContent.content: There are specific circumstances in which the use of deadly force is prohibited. Officers may not discharge their weapons or use other deadly force in the following situations:

items: To signal for help
To issue a warning shot
To prevent property damage or loss
To prevent the destruction of evidence
Against a person who poses a threat only to themselves and not to others

When there is imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or another person, created by a person in the vehicle using means other than the vehicle, such as when shots are being fired from the vehicle
When the suspect is driving their vehicle toward persons other than the officer in a manner creating an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury, such as in a terrorist attack
When the officer is being dragged or carried by the vehicle, cannot disengage from the vehicle, and is in imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury
When the suspect is driving a vehicle toward persons other than the officer in a manner creating an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury, such as in a terrorist attack; and
No other means are available at that time to avert or eliminate the danger

textContent.title: Weapon Surrender Policy
textContent.content: An officer shall not surrender their weapon unless it is the only alternative and only after the officer has used every tactical tool at the officer's disposal to avoid surrendering their weapon.

items: Maintain tactical positioning and distance
Use available cover and concealment
Request backup when possible
Utilize de-escalation techniques
Consider tactical retreat if it can be done safely
Sanctity of Human Life: Officers shall make every effort to preserve and protect human life and the safety of all persons.

Force as Last Resort: Force shall only be used as a last resort when necessary to accomplish lawful objectives that cannot reasonably be achieved through verbal commands, critical decision making, tactical deployment or de-escalation techniques.

Reasonable Force: Officers shall use the least amount of force that is objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional to safely achieve the legitimate law enforcement objective under the circumstances.
Deadly Force as Last Resort: Deadly force shall only be used as an absolute last resort and in strict compliance with department policy.

textContent.content: Remember: The primary duty of all law enforcement officers is to preserve human life. Only when no other means are available should an officer consider surrendering their weapon.

items: Types of subjects (Cooperative, Passive Resistor, Active Resistor, etc.)
Levels of resistance
Constructive authority

textContent.title: Subject Classifications
textContent.content: Understanding the different types of subjects officers may encounter is essential for determining the appropriate level of force that may be used in response.

items: Refuses to move when directed
Goes limp
Refuses to speak or respond to commands
Does not physically resist control measures

textContent.title: Force Classifications
textContent.content: The Cape May Police Department categorizes force into distinct types, each with specific applications, limitations, and reporting requirements.

items: Taking a resisting subject to the ground
Using wrist or arm locks
Striking the subject with the hands or feet
Other similar methods of hand-to-hand confrontation
Pain compliance techniques
Verbal commands
Gestures
Warnings
Unholstering a weapon
Pointing a firearm at a subject (only in appropriate circumstances)

textContent.title: Understanding CEDs
textContent.content: A Conducted Energy Device (CED) means any device approved by the Attorney General that is capable of firing darts/electrodes that transmit an electrical charge or current intended to temporarily disable a person.

items: Cartridge: A shell containing probes that penetrate the target and deliver neuromuscular incapacitation (NMI)
Data Download: The method of electronic recovery of the firing and video data saved by the CED upon activation
Discharge: To cause an electrical charge or current to be directed at a person in contact with the darts/electrodes
Drive Stun Mode: To discharge a CED when the main body of the device is in direct contact with the person against whom the charge or current is transmitted
An active assailant
A threatening assailant who will not voluntarily submit to custody after having been given a reasonable opportunity to do so
A person who is attempting to cause death or serious bodily injury to themselves
A fleeing suspect, if clear and convincing evidence exists to believe the suspect has committed a crime in which the suspect caused or attempted to cause death or serious bodily injury
A CED shall not be used or threatened to be used to retaliate for any past conduct or to impose punishment
A CED shall not be used against a person who is a passive resistor or an active resistor
A CED shall not be fired or discharged for the sole purpose of preventing a person from committing property damage
A CED shall not be deployed against the operator of a moving vehicle unless the use of deadly force against the operator of the motor vehicle would be authorized
A CED shall not be used against a person in drive stun mode more than twice unless deadly force would be authorized
Two or more CEDs shall not be discharged upon a person at the same time

textContent.title: Safety Protocols for CED Use
textContent.content: While CEDs are considered less-lethal devices, they still require careful consideration and adherence to safety protocols to minimize risks to subjects and officers.

items: To ensure officer safety, when feasible, at least one law enforcement officer other than the one deploying the CED should be present
The second officer should be armed with lethal ammunition and be prepared to utilize deadly force if the use of a CED fails
Deadly force would only be authorized in this situation as a last resort, if otherwise permitted by department policy
During the deployment of a CED, the deploying officer shall, when feasible, continually evaluate the options selected against changing circumstances
Officers trained and authorized to carry a CED shall be aware of and comply with any targeting recommendations made by the manufacturer
Deadly force would be authorized under department policy; and
The use of physical or mechanical force is not feasible or would be ineffective

textContent.title: Understanding Less-Lethal Options
textContent.content: Less-lethal devices and ammunition provide officers with additional force options that are designed to temporarily incapacitate a subject without causing death or serious injury.

items:
An officer may fire or discharge a less-lethal device during an actual operation, only against:
                
                    An active assailant
                    A threatening assailant who will not voluntarily submit to custody after given a reasonable opportunity
                    A person attempting to cause death or serious bodily injury to themselves
                    A fleeing suspect if clear and convincing evidence exists to believe the suspect has committed a crime causing or attempting to cause death or serious bodily injury
An active assailant
A threatening assailant who will not voluntarily submit to custody after given a reasonable opportunity
A person attempting to cause death or serious bodily injury to themselves
A fleeing suspect if clear and convincing evidence exists to believe the suspect has committed a crime causing or attempting to cause death or serious bodily injury
Intentionally aiming approved less-lethal impact ammunition at the head, neck, chest and groin should be avoided unless deadly force is justified, necessary and appropriate
No ammunition designed to be skip-fired, and/or non-target specific will be deemed acceptable
Weapons used for the deployment of less than lethal platforms or ammunition shall be dedicated exclusively for that purpose
These weapons shall be clearly marked to distinguish them from firearms intended for the use of lethal ammunition
Less-lethal devices or ammunition shall not be used in a crowd management situation except against specific threatening assailants or active assailants
Less-lethal devices or ammunition shall not be used to prevent a person from causing property damage
A less-lethal device shall not be directed against a person who is situated on an elevated surface unless reasonable efforts have been made to prevent or minimize a fall-related injury

textContent.title: Understanding Mechanical Force
textContent.content: Mechanical force involves the use of a device or substance, other than a firearm, to overcome a subject's resistance to the exertion of the officer's authority. Common mechanical force options include batons and OC spray.

items: Batons are defensive impact tools that may be used when the justification for the use of mechanical force exists
Batons shall only be used as instructed
Once resistance ceases, the use of the baton as a striking tool shall cease
Officers must exercise special care in their use and avoid striking potentially fatal areas of the body identified during training except when deadly force is otherwise authorized
Any strikes to the head or neck with a baton or asp are considered deadly force and can only be used when deadly force is allowed
If a baton is used, officers shall observe the affected subject(s) for obvious changes in condition or breathing
Officers shall immediately summon medical assistance if the subject appears to need medical aid
OC shall not be used in the immediate vicinity of infants or the elderly unless necessary
OC shall not be used on the operator of a motor vehicle unless the motor vehicle is first disabled (e.g., removal of keys from the ignition)
Once resistance ceases, the further application of OC shall cease
In crowd control situations, OC spray may be used against specific individuals who are active resistors, threatening assailants or active assailants
OC spray shall not be used where bystanders would be unreasonably affected
OC spray shall not be used against passive resistors, or indiscriminately against groups of people
Extreme mental and physiological excitement
Intense agitation
Hyperthermia often resulting in nudity
Hostility
Exceptional strength
Endurance without fatigue
Unusual calmness after restraint

textContent.title: Understanding the Force Continuum
textContent.content: The force continuum is a model that illustrates the relationship between subject behavior and appropriate officer response. It helps officers understand what level of force is appropriate based on the level of resistance encountered.

textContent.header: Key Principles of the Force Continuum
items: The level of resistance that an officer encounters is a key factor in determining the appropriate amount of force that may be used in response
The less resistance an officer faces, the less force the officer should use
If the individual's resistance diminishes, the officer shall immediately reduce the level of force used
If the individual stops resisting entirely, the officer must immediately cease using force
Force must always be objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional to the threat faced

textContent.content: Remember: The force continuum is not a rigid, step-by-step progression. Officers may need to immediately employ a higher level of force based on the totality of circumstances, including the immediacy and severity of the threat.

slide_24.title: Key Definitions: Bodily Injury and Serious Bodily Injury

textContent.title: Understanding Injury Classifications
textContent.content: The distinction between bodily injury and serious bodily injury is critical in use of force decision-making, as it affects the level of force that may be justified in a given situation.

items: Injuries creating substantial risk of death
Significant or permanent disfigurement
Dismemberment
Significant bone fractures
Loss of consciousness
Protracted loss or impairment of function of any bodily member or organ
Significant internal injuries

textContent.header: Importance in Use of Force Decisions
items: Deadly Force Justification: Deadly force may only be used when the officer reasonably believes that such action is immediately necessary to protect the officer or another person from imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury.
Enhanced Mechanical Force: Enhanced mechanical force (such as CEDs) may be used against threatening assailants who may cause bodily injury (not necessarily serious bodily injury).
Reporting Requirements: Any use of force resulting in serious bodily injury must be immediately reported to the Chief of Police and the Cape May County Prosecutor's Office.
Administrative Review: An officer involved in a use of force incident where death or serious injury occurs shall be reassigned to administrative duties pending review of the incident.

textContent.content: Critical Distinction: Understanding the difference between bodily injury and serious bodily injury helps officers make appropriate decisions about the level of force that is reasonable, necessary, and proportional in a given situation.

textContent.title: Understanding Imminent Danger
textContent.content: Imminent danger is a critical concept in use of force decision-making, particularly when considering the use of deadly force or enhanced mechanical force.

items: Immediacy: The threat is about to happen or is in the process of happening
Capability: The subject has the means to carry out the threatened harm
Opportunity: The subject is in a position to carry out the threatened harm
Intent: The subject's actions or words indicate a willingness to cause harm
Jeopardy: The officer or another person is at risk of death or serious bodily injury

textContent.header: Importance in Use of Force Decisions
items: Deadly Force: An officer may use deadly force only when the officer reasonably believes that such action is immediately necessary to protect the officer or another person from imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury.

Threatening vs. Active Assailant: When dealing with an individual who poses a threat to the officer, the individual could be considered either a threatening assailant or an active assailant. To determine the individual's status for appropriate officer response, the officer must assess whether the threat poses an imminent danger. If the threat is imminent, then that individual is considered an active assailant.

Reasonable Belief: The officer's assessment of imminent danger must be based on a reasonable belief, which is an objective assessment based upon an evaluation of how a reasonable officer with comparable training and experience would react to, or draw inferences from, the facts and circumstances confronting and known by the officer at the scene.

slide_26.title: Key Definitions: Feasible and Proportional Force

textContent.title: Understanding Feasibility and Proportionality
textContent.content: The concepts of feasibility and proportional force are essential components of the Cape May Police Department's use of force policy, guiding officers in making appropriate decisions about when and how to use force.

items: What is feasible in one situation may not be feasible in another
Feasibility depends on the totality of the circumstances
Time constraints may impact what is feasible
Available resources affect feasibility
Officer safety considerations must be taken into account
Public safety must be maintained
Officers must use the least amount of force that is feasible in the circumstances
The force used must be proportional to the threat or resistance encountered
Officers must continuously reassess both what is feasible and what is proportional as the situation evolves
If a less forceful alternative is feasible and would achieve the same objective, that alternative should be used
If the level of resistance changes, the proportional force response must also change

textContent.content: Remember: Officers shall use the least amount of force that is objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional to safely achieve the legitimate law enforcement objective under the circumstances.

textContent.title: Understanding Reasonable Belief
textContent.content: Reasonable belief is a foundational concept in use of force decision-making, serving as the standard by which officer actions are evaluated.

items: Immediacy and severity of the threat
Subject's actions and behavior
Officer's perception of the subject's intentions
Subject's proximity to weapons
Environmental conditions (lighting, weather, terrain)
Number of subjects vs. number of officers
Size, age, and physical capabilities of the subject compared to the officer

Graham v. Connor (1989): Established that use of force must be objectively reasonable based on the facts and circumstances confronting the officer, without regard to the officer's underlying intent or motivation.

Tennessee v. Garner (1985): Established that deadly force may not be used unless it is necessary to prevent the escape of a fleeing felon who poses a significant threat of death or serious physical injury to the officer or others.

textContent.content: Important Note: The reasonable belief standard recognizes that law enforcement officers are often forced to make split-second judgments in circumstances that are tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving. The assessment of reasonableness must allow for the fact that police officers are often forced to make difficult decisions with limited information in dangerous situations.

textContent.title: Understanding Prohibited Neck Restraints
textContent.content: Chokeholds and similar neck restraint techniques are classified as deadly force and are prohibited except in extraordinary circumstances when the officer's life is in danger and deadly force is authorized.

items: Can cause death or serious bodily injury
May lead to unconsciousness within seconds
Can cause damage to the trachea, larynx, or cervical spine
May trigger cardiac arrest or stroke
Particularly dangerous for individuals with pre-existing medical conditions
Difficult to apply with precision in dynamic situations
Effects can be unpredictable and vary between individuals
The officer's life is in danger
Deadly force is authorized
No other means of defense are available
New Jersey state law and Attorney General directives
The principle that deadly force should only be used as an absolute last resort
The duty to respect and preserve human life
The requirement to use only objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional force

textContent.content: Critical Warning: Under no circumstances shall an officer use a chokehold, or any lesser contact with the neck area, in order to prevent the destruction of evidence by ingestion.

textContent.title: Use of Force in Crowd Situations
textContent.content: The Cape May Police Department has specific restrictions and limitations on the use of force during peaceful demonstrations and civil disturbances. These guidelines help ensure appropriate responses while respecting constitutional rights.

items: Provide clear instructions and warnings in a manner that can be heard by persons in the crowd, such as through a bullhorn or speaker system when available
State the consequences of refusing to comply with a mandatory directive, including that arrests will occur and force may be used unless persons comply
Give a reasonable opportunity to comply
Bodily injury
Significant property damage
Looting
Other criminal acts

textContent.content: Important Note: Force may be used against specific individuals in a crowd for lawful purposes in accordance with the other provisions of the Use of Force Policy. The focus should always be on addressing specific unlawful behavior rather than taking action against an entire crowd.

textContent.title: Key Concepts from Module 2: Definitions and Classifications
textContent.content: This module covered essential terminology and classifications that form the foundation of the Cape May Police Department's Use of Force policy.

items: Bodily Injury: Physical pain, temporary disfigurement, or impairment
Serious Bodily Injury: Injury creating substantial risk of death, permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss of function
Imminent Danger: Threatened actions immediately likely to occur
Feasible: Reasonably capable of being accomplished given circumstances
Proportional Force: Minimum force necessary to control situation
Reasonable Belief: Objective assessment based on facts known at the time
Sanctity of Human Life: Officers shall make every effort to preserve and protect human life
Force as Last Resort: Force shall only be used as a last resort when necessary
Reasonable Force: Officers shall use only objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional force
Deadly Force as Last Resort: Deadly force shall only be used as an absolute last resort

textContent.content: Next Module: Module 3 will cover Procedures and Techniques, including de-escalation techniques, critical decision-making, force continuum application, and special considerations for subjects with mental health issues or other conditions affecting compliance.

items: De-escalation techniques in practice
Critical decision-making model application
Force continuum implementation

textContent.title: Applying De-escalation Effectively
textContent.content: De-escalation is the action of communicating verbally or nonverbally to reduce, stabilize, or eliminate the immediacy of a threat. When properly applied, these techniques can prevent the need to use force or reduce the level of force necessary.

items: Tone and Pitch Control: Speak slowly in a calm, measured voice
Simple Commands: Use clear, concise language
One Officer Speaking: Designate a single officer as the communicator
Active Listening: Show genuine interest in the subject's concerns
Introduce Yourself: "My name is Officer [Name]. I'm here to help."
Explain Actions: "I'm doing this because..."
Offer Options: Present choices rather than ultimatums when possible

textContent.content: Remember: Officers should not default to attempting to resolve the incident immediately if slowing down the pace is viable and can be accomplished without creating an immediate threat to the public or placing officers in unreasonable danger.

textContent.title: Applying the Critical Decision-Making Model
textContent.content: The Critical Decision-Making Model (CDM) is an organized way of making decisions about how an officer will act in any situation, including those that may involve potential uses of force.

items: Begin critical assessment and planning prior to arriving at the scene
Gather information from dispatch, witnesses, and observations
Consider what is known and what is unknown
Identify potential resources needed (backup, specialized units)
Collect Information: Dispatch reports the subject is yelling and appears agitated. No weapons reported. Officer observes subject pacing and talking to themselves.
Assess Threats/Risks: Subject does not appear to be threatening others but is in distress. Possible mental health crisis. Park has families present.
Authority/Limitations: Officer has authority to contact subject for welfare check. Mental health resources available through dispatch.
Options/Best Course: Approach calmly, maintain distance, use de-escalation techniques, request mental health resources.
Act/Reassess: Officer approaches, introduces self, speaks calmly. Subject responds positively to de-escalation. Officer continues to monitor while waiting for mental health team.

textContent.content: Remember: The CDM is not linear—it's a continuous process. Officers should constantly reassess as new information becomes available and conditions change. The core values of ethics, professionalism, and the sanctity of human life should guide every decision.

textContent.title: Applying the Force Continuum in Real Situations
textContent.content: The force continuum provides a framework for officers to select the appropriate level of force based on the subject's behavior. Proper implementation requires continuous assessment and adjustment as the situation evolves.

items: Dynamic Assessment: Continuously evaluate the subject's behavior and level of resistance
Proportional Response: Match your force response to the level of resistance encountered
De-escalation: Reduce force as resistance decreases
Communication: Maintain verbal commands throughout the encounter
Documentation: Record all force used and the justification for each level
Initial Assessment: Subject is a passive resistor (refusing commands but not physically resisting)
Appropriate Response: Verbal commands, explanation of legal requirements, clear consequences of non-compliance
Scenario Evolution 1: Subject complies after explanation → De-escalate to cooperative person level
Scenario Evolution 2: Subject exits vehicle and attempts to walk away → Escalate to active resistor response (control holds)
Scenario Evolution 3: Subject becomes compliant after being detained → De-escalate force while maintaining control

textContent.content: Remember: The force continuum is not a rigid, step-by-step progression. It is a flexible framework that guides decision-making based on the totality of circumstances. Officers must continuously assess and adjust their force response as the situation evolves.

textContent.title: Special Considerations for Mental Health Crises
textContent.content: Encounters with individuals experiencing mental health crises require specialized approaches to de-escalation and force considerations. Officers must recognize signs of mental illness and adapt their response accordingly.

items: Disorientation or confusion
Unusual or rapid speech patterns
Inappropriate emotional responses
Hallucinations or delusions
Paranoia or extreme suspicion
Impaired decision-making
Extreme agitation or withdrawal
Statements about suicide or self-harm
Bizarre or irrational behavior
Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): Mental illness may qualify as a disability requiring reasonable accommodations in police interactions
Involuntary Commitment: Understand criteria and procedures for emergency psychiatric evaluation
Use of Force Justification: Mental illness alone does not justify increased force, but may require modified approaches
Duty of Care: Officers have a responsibility to recognize and respond appropriately to mental health crises
Maintain safe distance and observe behavior
Request CIT officer and/or mental health resources
Use calm, clear communication with simple directions
Avoid rushing the interaction or forcing compliance unnecessarily
Focus on de-escalation rather than enforcement when possible
Consider whether the person needs medical or psychiatric assistance rather than arrest

textContent.content: Remember: The goal in mental health crisis situations is to resolve the encounter safely for all involved, connect the person with appropriate resources, and avoid unnecessary use of force or criminal charges when possible. Mental illness is a medical condition, not a crime.

textContent.title: Effective Positioning and Communication Strategies
textContent.content: Proper tactical positioning and communication techniques can significantly reduce the need for physical force by creating time and distance advantages that enhance officer safety and facilitate de-escalation.

items: Contact/Cover: One officer communicates while another maintains security
Reactionary Gap: Maintain 6-8 feet distance when possible
Tactical L or V: Position at angles rather than directly in front
Triangulation: Multiple officers position at different angles
High Ground: Position at elevation advantage when available
Cover vs. Concealment: Utilize physical barriers that stop bullets (cover) or hide position (concealment)
Ask: Make a professional request
Set Context: Explain why you're making the request
Present Options: Good choices vs. poor choices
Confirm: Ask if they understand
Act: Take appropriate action based on response
Ask: Professional tone
Tell: Command voice
Challenge: Present options and consequences
Warning: Final opportunity to comply
Action: Appropriate force response
Hearing Impaired: Position in full view, use visual cues, consider written communication
Limited English: Simple commands, universal gestures, translator when available
Mental Illness: Increased distance, reduce stimuli, slow pace, clear communication
Elderly/Disabled: Adjust expectations for movement, provide additional time to comply
Children: Lower positioning to eye level, simplified language, non-threatening approach

textContent.content: Making advantageous uses of position, distance, and cover to reduce the risk of injury and avoid or reduce the need to use force.
Verbal communication techniques that are designed to avoid or minimize the use of force.

textContent.title: Proper Application of Control Techniques
textContent.content: Defensive tactics and pain compliance techniques are physical control methods that may be effective in controlling passive or active resistors. These techniques must be applied properly, with consideration for their effectiveness and potential for injury.

items: Potential for injury to officer(s) or others if technique is not used
Potential risk of serious injury to the individual being controlled
Effectiveness of the technique in achieving appropriate control
Whether a different technique should be employed
Nature of the offense involved
Level of resistance of the individual(s)
Whether immediate resolution is necessary
Recognition: Quickly identify when a technique is not working
Communication: Verbalize to partners when transitioning
Coordination: Work together with other officers during transitions
Control: Maintain control during the transition between techniques
Escalation/De-escalation: Move up or down the force continuum as appropriate
Secure: Properly handcuff or otherwise secure the subject
Position: Place the subject in a recovery position that does not impede breathing
Assess: Check for injuries or medical distress
Monitor: Continuously observe the subject's condition
Document: Record the techniques used, reason for use, and subject's response

textContent.content: Officers may only utilize pain compliance techniques that the officer has received department approved training on and only when the officer reasonably believes that the use of such a technique is necessary to further a legitimate law enforcement purpose.

Important: The application of any pain compliance technique shall be immediately discontinued once the officer determines that compliance has been achieved or other more appropriate alternatives can be reasonably utilized. Always be alert to the risks of positional asphyxiation during and after the application of control techniques.

textContent.title: Key Concepts from Module 3: Procedures and Techniques
textContent.content: This module covered essential procedures and techniques for effectively implementing the Cape May Police Department's Use of Force policy in real-world situations.

items: Communication strategies to reduce tension
Verbal and non-verbal de-escalation methods
Active listening and empathy
Slowing down the pace of encounters
Creating time and distance
Sanctity of Human Life: De-escalation techniques and tactical positioning help preserve life by reducing the need for physical force
Force as Last Resort: The Critical Decision-Making Model helps officers identify alternatives to force
Reasonable Force: Force continuum implementation ensures proportional response to resistance
Deadly Force as Last Resort: Proper application of less-lethal options reduces the need for deadly force
De-escalation attempts made before force was used
Subject's actions and level of resistance

How the incident was resolved

textContent.content: Next Module: Module 4 will cover Specific Force Options, including detailed information on Conducted Energy Devices (CEDs), less-lethal devices, deadly force requirements, and prohibited uses of force.

items: Conducted Energy Devices (CEDs)
Less-lethal devices and ammunition
OC spray and chemical agents

textContent.title: Operational Guidelines for CEDs
textContent.content: Conducted Energy Devices (CEDs) are enhanced mechanical force options that may be utilized against a Threatening Assailant or an Active Assailant. Proper training, deployment, and post-deployment procedures are essential for safe and effective use.

items: Against passive resistors or active resistors
For retaliation or punishment
To prevent property damage
Against operator of moving vehicle unless deadly force is authorized
In drive stun mode more than twice unless deadly force would be authorized
Multiple CEDs discharged upon a person at the same time
Against handcuffed subjects unless deadly force would be authorized and physical/mechanical force is not feasible
The subject requests medical attention
The subject had been rendered unconscious or unresponsive
The subject, after being subjected to a discharge, does not appear to have recovered normally
The subject has exhibited signs of excited delirium
The subject has suffered bodily injury requiring medical attention
The subject was exposed to three or more discharges
The subject has been exposed to a continuous discharge lasting 15 seconds or more
No one present is qualified to remove CED darts/electrodes
An officer has trouble removing a dart/electrode
Any part of a CED dart/electrode has broken off and remains embedded
Electronic Use of Force Report through the Attorney General's Use of Force Reporting Portal
Conducted Energy Device Deployment Review Report
Investigation Report and/or Supplemental Report
Information stored in the device concerning its use
Time the weapon was fired
Time of all electrical discharges
BWC recordings of the firing and discharges

textContent.content: Remember: CEDs are enhanced mechanical force options that should only be used when necessary and justified. Officers shall reevaluate the situation and reassess the need to use force before any second or subsequent firing or discharge against the same person.

textContent.title: Understanding Deadly Force Authorization
textContent.content: Deadly force shall only be used as an absolute last resort and in strict compliance with department policy. Officers must understand the specific requirements that must be met before deadly force may be used.

items: Firearms: Discharging a firearm at a person
Neck Restraints: Applying a chokehold, carotid artery restraint, or similar technique that involves pressure on the neck
Positional Asphyxia Risk: Sitting, kneeling, or standing on a person's chest, back, or neck for a prolonged period of time
Vehicle Tactics: Intentionally driving a vehicle at or in the direction of a person with the intent to strike the individual
Impact Weapons: Using a baton or other weapon to intentionally strike an individual in the head or neck area
Clear evidence that the suspect poses an ongoing threat of death or serious bodily injury
Reasonable belief that the suspect's escape would endanger others
No reasonable alternative means to apprehend the suspect safely
Officers shall never intentionally position themselves in the path of a moving vehicle or a vehicle that is likely to move
Officers shall make every effort to move out of the path of a vehicle to maintain their safety
Officers shall not grab onto moving vehicles or the drivers or occupants of moving vehicles
If a vehicle begins to move while an officer is engaged with the driver or an occupant, the officer shall, if feasible, disengage from the contact

When there is imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury to the officer or another person, created by a person in the vehicle using means other than the vehicle, such as when shots are being fired from the vehicle
When the suspect is driving their vehicle toward persons other than the officer in a manner creating an imminent threat of death or serious bodily injury, such as in a terrorist attack
When the officer is being dragged or carried by the vehicle, cannot disengage from the vehicle, and is in imminent danger of death or serious bodily injury

textContent.content: Critical Reminder: Deadly force is an absolute last resort. Officers must exhaust all other reasonable means before resorting to deadly force. The decision to use deadly force must be based on the facts and circumstances known to the officer at the time, not on information learned later.

textContent.title: Understanding Less-Lethal Force Options
textContent.content: Less-lethal devices and ammunition provide officers with enhanced mechanical force options that are designed to temporarily incapacitate a subject without causing death or serious bodily injury when properly deployed.

items: Impact projectiles (foam, rubber, or plastic)
Bean bag rounds
Baton rounds
Sponge grenades
When it can be reasonably accomplished without increasing danger, advise other officers at the scene prior to discharge
This minimizes the possibility that the firing would provoke other officers to discharge their weapons
Assess the subject's position and surroundings for risks (elevated surfaces, water, etc.)
Consider distance to target and manufacturer's recommended range
Ensure proper weapon selection and ammunition loading
Maintain proper distance according to manufacturer specifications
Target approved areas of the body
Continually evaluate the options selected against changing circumstances
Reassess the need for force before any second or subsequent firing
Secure the subject
Assess for injuries
Provide medical care as needed
Transport to medical facility for examination if subject suffers bodily injury or requests medical treatment
Document the use of force thoroughly
Less-lethal devices or ammunition shall not be used in a crowd management situation except against specific threatening assailants or active assailants
Less-lethal devices or ammunition shall not be used to prevent a person from causing property damage
A less-lethal device shall not be directed against a person who is situated on an elevated surface unless reasonable efforts have been made to prevent or minimize a fall-related injury
The use of other than less-lethal ammunition in designated weapons is prohibited unless immediately necessary to protect the life of an officer or other person, and there is no other means available

textContent.content: An officer authorized to use a less-lethal device may fire or discharge the device during an actual operation, only against:

Remember: Less-lethal does not mean non-lethal. These devices can cause serious injury or death if improperly used. Officers must be properly trained, follow manufacturer guidelines, and continuously reassess the situation during deployment.

textContent.title: Oleoresin Capsicum (OC) Spray
textContent.content: OC spray is a mechanical force option that uses capsaicin-based inflammatory agents to cause temporary discomfort and disorientation. When properly used, it can help officers control subjects with minimal risk of injury to all parties.

items: Spray directly into the target's face
Direct spray to the eyes, nose, and mouth
Apply from as close as safely possible
Use short one-half to one-second bursts
Follow manufacturer's recommendations
Maintain safe distance to avoid contamination
Be aware of wind direction and environmental factors
Mentally Disturbed Persons: May not respond to pain or discomfort
Intoxicated Persons: May have diminished sensitivity to effects
Excited Delirium: May be ineffective due to elevated pain threshold
Highly Motivated Individuals: May fight through the effects
Environmental Factors: Wind, rain, or extreme temperatures may reduce effectiveness
Ventilation systems may spread OC to unintended areas
Contact with contaminated persons may transfer OC to officers
Vehicles used to transport exposed subjects may become contaminated
Processing areas may need decontamination after exposure
Justification for OC spray use
Subject's actions and level of resistance
Warnings given (if feasible)

Decontamination procedures provided

Effectiveness of OC spray
Any injuries or complaints

textContent.content: Remember: Once resistance ceases, the further application of OC shall cease. Officers shall remain alert for medical problems or difficulty that the exposed subject may experience and monitor for positional asphyxiation.

textContent.title: Tactical Batons and Impact Techniques
textContent.content: Impact weapons, primarily batons, are defensive tools that may be used when the justification for the use of mechanical force exists. These tools require proper training and technique to be used safely and effectively.

items: When mechanical force is necessary and justified
To overcome resistance directed at the officer or others
To protect the officer or third party from unlawful force
To prevent physical harm to the officer or another person
As a control device for non-impact pressure techniques
Clothing: Heavy or bulky clothing may reduce impact effectiveness
Subject Size: Larger subjects may be less affected by strikes
Drugs/Alcohol: Intoxicated subjects may have reduced pain sensitivity
Excited Delirium: Subjects may have elevated pain threshold
Confined Spaces: Limited room to deploy effectively
Close Quarters: Risk of weapon retention issues
Justification for impact weapon use
Subject's actions and level of resistance
Warnings given (if feasible)
Specific techniques used
Target areas struck
Number of strikes
Effectiveness of techniques
Medical assessment and treatment
Any injuries observed or reported

textContent.content: Remember: Impact weapons are defensive tools. The primary goal is to gain control with minimal injury. Once control is achieved, the use of impact weapons must cease immediately.

textContent.title: Understanding Force Prohibitions
textContent.content: The Cape May Police Department strictly prohibits certain uses of force. Understanding these prohibitions is essential for lawful and ethical policing. Violations may result in disciplinary action, up to and including criminal prosecution and/or termination.

items: Against passive resistors or active resistors
For retaliation or punishment
To prevent property damage
Against operator of moving vehicle unless deadly force is authorized
In drive stun mode more than twice unless deadly force would be authorized
Multiple CEDs discharged upon a person at the same time
Against handcuffed subjects unless deadly force would be authorized and physical/mechanical force is not feasible
Officers must intervene to prevent any use of force that is illegal, excessive, or otherwise inconsistent with department policy
Intervention may include verbal or physical actions to stop the improper use of force
Officers must notify a supervisor as soon as possible after observing or learning of improper force
Officers must submit an individual written report before reporting off duty on the day they become aware of the misconduct
Supervisors must report the incident to internal affairs
Retaliation against officers who intervene or report is prohibited
Administrative review
Disciplinary action
Remedial training
Suspension
Termination
Criminal prosecution
Civil liability

textContent.content: Critical Reminder: The prohibitions outlined in this policy are not exhaustive. Officers must always use sound judgment and ensure that any force used is objectively reasonable, necessary, and proportional to the threat or resistance encountered.

textContent.title: Core Principle Six: Duty to Render Medical Assistance
textContent.content: After any use of force, and when the environment is safe, officers shall promptly render medical assistance to any injured person consistent with the officer's training and shall promptly request emergency medical assistance for that person, if needed or requested.

items: Sit the subject upright as soon as practicable
Expose to fresh air and encourage calm breathing
Flush affected areas with large amounts of fresh water
Read the department's Decontamination Statement
Do not apply salves, creams, oils, lotion, grease, or bandages
Transport to hospital if wearing contact lenses

Summon medical assistance if:
                        
                            Subject has medical problems
                            Continues to have difficulty after decontamination
                            Requests medical treatment
                            Inflammation/discomfort continues beyond 45 minutes
Subject has medical problems
Continues to have difficulty after decontamination
Requests medical treatment
Inflammation/discomfort continues beyond 45 minutes
An officer is authorized to remove a CED dart/electrode from a subject only if the officer has received training on dart/electrode removal
Officers are not authorized to remove a CED dart/electrode from any part of the person's head or neck, or when the dart/electrode is in the subject's genitalia, or female breast
In the absence of exigent circumstances requiring immediate action, only qualified medical personnel can remove a CED dart/electrode from these areas
Officers shall wear protective gloves during dart/electrode removal
Darts/electrodes shall be handled as a biohazard risk and secured as evidence
Any person requesting and/or deemed in need of medical attention shall be transported to the nearest available emergency medical treatment center or hospital
Officers shall contact EMS/BLS to request such transportation assistance
Officers shall not transport the subject in a department vehicle
The extent of the injury and the treatment offered/provided shall be documented in the Investigation Report
The duty to render medical assistance and monitor applies to all officers on scene and continues throughout any transportation and custody of the individual

textContent.content: Remember: The duty to render medical assistance is a core principle of the Cape May Police Department's Use of Force policy. Providing prompt and appropriate medical care after a use of force incident is not only a legal and ethical obligation but also helps build trust with the community.

textContent.title: Core Principle Seven: Duty to Report and Review Uses of Force
textContent.content: Every use of force must be reported and receive a meaningful/administrative command level review as set forth in a written department policy that includes review by the law enforcement executive.

items: A superior officer shall investigate the circumstances and outcome
A superior officer designated by the Chief shall prepare a report regarding the information stored in the device
Report must contain information related to the time the weapon was fired, the time of all electrical discharges, and BWC recordings
Information shall be preserved consistent with retention schedules
The superior officer shall forward the report to the Chief of Police
The Chief of Police shall issue a finding on whether the firing and discharges complied with policy
The Chief of Police shall forward the case report, CED data log(s), and any associated recording(s) to the County Prosecutor within 10 business days
Notify a supervisor as soon as possible
Submit an individual written report to a supervisor as soon as possible on the day the officer becomes aware of this incident
The reason for the initial police presence
A specific description of the acts that led to the use of force
The level of resistance encountered
A description of every type of force used
De-escalation efforts attempted
Use of warnings before force was used
Injuries sustained by the subject and/or officer
Medical care provided or offered
Names and contact information of witnesses
Name and badge number of all officers involved
Name of supervisor notified and time of notification

textContent.content: Remember: Thorough and accurate reporting is essential for transparency, accountability, and continuous improvement. Reports should be completed promptly and should contain all relevant details about the use of force incident.
